Details.Description: This file includes the persona of an individual interviewed using the Jobs-to-be-Done (JTBD) framework for a new product. It also contains the full transcript of the qualitative interview, documenting the conversation between the interviewer and the individual.

persona.name: Jamie Brown
persona.background_story: Jamie grew up in a middle-class family in a small town in Texas. From a young age, she was inspired by her mother's compassionate work in a local clinic, sparking her interest in healthcare. Her strong affinity for helping others led her to pursue a career in nursing. Jamie moved to Austin for college and decided to stay for the vibrant community and career opportunities. She's highly family-oriented, driven by the values of empathy, responsibility, and community service.

psychographics.values_and_beliefs: Jamie values honesty, empathy, and dedication. Her career choice is heavily influenced by her belief in making a tangible difference in people's lives.

behavioral_traits.emotional_resilience: Jamie manages stress well, finding balance through outdoor activities and meditation.

emotional_triggers.positive_triggers: Feeling appreciated and seeing her patients recover bring Jamie joy.
emotional_triggers.negative_triggers: Confrontations and witnessing injustice can make her uncomfortable.

motivations.emotional_motivations: Accomplishing goals and seeing positive outcomes in patient care

challenges.personal_challenges: Maintaining work-life balance and managing stress
challenges.professional_challenges: Keeping up with medical advancements and balancing patient care with administrative duties
challenges.communication_challenges: Articulating emotions under stress can be challenging for Jamie.

life_outside_work.social_circle: Jamie has a close-knit group of friends from college and work.

family_life.importance_of_family: Family is a central motivator for Jamie; they are her support system.
family_life.family_role: She often plays the role of supporter and confidant in her family.

life_outside_work.community_involvement: Jamie participates in health fairs and volunteers at local shelters.

professional_goals.short_term_goals: Earning a certification in critical care nursing
professional_goals.long_term_goals: Becoming a nurse practitioner and opening a community health clinic

frustrations_pain_points.personal_frustrations: Limited time for personal projects and self-care
frustrations_pain_points.professional_frustrations: Bureaucratic delays and inadequate staffing at times
frustrations_pain_points.communication_frustrations: Feeling misunderstood when overwhelmed by work pressures

daily_tasks.personal_routine: Commutes to work, exercises through yoga, spends weekends hiking, and catching up with family.
daily_tasks.work_routine: Starts the day with a handover meeting, checks patient charts, administers medication, and coordinates with healthcare teams.

cognitive_biases.optimism_bias: Jamie is generally confident in her ability to handle her responsibilities efficiently.
cognitive_biases.confirmation_bias: She tends to seek healthcare practices that align with her belief in patient-centered care.
cognitive_biases.anchoring_bias: Previous successes guide her optimism in patient outcomes.
cognitive_biases.availability_bias: Her experiences in emergency situations often shape her quick decision-making.

response_to_interview_context.adaptability_during_interviews: Jamie adjusts well to unexpected questions, using them as opportunities to learn.

customer_journey.awareness_stage: Jamie becomes aware of new healthcare products through professional networking and seminars.
customer_journey.consideration_stage: She evaluates products based on professional reviews and practical applications.
customer_journey.decision_stage: Recommendations from trusted colleagues and product quality
customer_journey.post_purchase_behavior: Jamie tends to advocate for products that prove effective, sharing her experiences with peers.

transcript.text: Hello, I'm [Your Name], and I'm really excited to talk with you today. Thank you for taking the time to join me. To start, could you please tell me a little bit about your current role and daily routine as a nurse?

Hi, it's great to be here with you! I'm Jamie, and I'm a registered nurse working in Austin, Texas. My daily routine starts with a handover meeting where we get updates on patient statuses. After that, I check patient charts and administer medications. Throughout the day, I coordinate with healthcare teams to make sure everything is running smoothly. I also spend a lot of time interacting with patients, making sure they're comfortable and their needs are being met. It can be pretty busy, but I love the challenge and the difference I get to make in people's lives.

Thank you, Jamie, for sharing that. It sounds like you have a very dynamic and impactful role. I appreciate you giving us a glimpse into your routine. How important are the shoes you wear during your shifts?

Oh, they're super important! I’m on my feet most of the day, so having a good pair of comfortable, supportive shoes is a must. They really make a difference in how I feel by the end of a long shift. If my feet are hurting, it really impacts my ability to stay focused and do my job effectively.

I can imagine that being on your feet all day can take a toll, especially without the right footwear. Could you describe a memorable experience where your footwear impacted your workday, either positively or negatively?

Sure! There was this one time when I wore a new pair of shoes that I hadn't broken in yet. Big mistake—they ended up giving me blisters and made it really uncomfortable to get through the day. Since then, I always make sure to try out new shoes at home first before wearing them for a long shift. On the flip side, when I wear shoes that are broken in and comfy, like my favorite pair, I hardly even notice my feet at all, and I can focus on my patients without distraction. It definitely reinforces how crucial good shoes are in my line of work.
That sounds like a tough experience, and I'm glad you learned a way to avoid it in the future. How often do you find yourself needing to replace your work shoes?

Typically, I end up replacing my work shoes every six months or so. With all the walking and standing I do, they start to wear out and lose support after a while, and I can really feel the difference by then. It’s just one of those things I have to keep an eye on for my own comfort and effectiveness at work.
It sounds like you have a good sense of when your shoes need replacing. When you’re shopping for new work shoes, what are the primary factors you consider?

When I’m shopping for work shoes, comfort and support are the main things I look for. I need a pair that can handle long hours on my feet without causing discomfort. I also consider durability because I want them to last as long as possible. Of course, slip-resistance is important too since safety is a big factor in my work environment. If they happen to look nice, that’s a bonus, but it’s not a top priority for me.

I see, those all sound like crucial factors. Could you tell me more about what specifically makes a shoe comfortable for you? Are there particular features you look for that contribute to that comfort?

Definitely! For me, a comfortable shoe usually has good arch support and plenty of cushioning. I really like shoes with breathable materials too, so my feet don’t get too hot during the day. A roomy toe box is also important to prevent any squeezing or discomfort in the toes. And, of course, a supportive sole that can absorb the impact from walking and standing all day is a must. These features together really help keep my feet happy during long shifts.

That makes a lot of sense and provides a clear picture of what you're looking for. Moving on to support, what type of support do you specifically look for in a shoe and how does it affect your performance during your shifts?

I look for shoes with strong arch support and a stable heel. Good arch support helps prevent foot fatigue and pain, which is really important when I'm standing and moving around all day. A stable heel keeps me feeling balanced and secure, which is crucial in a busy hospital setting where there's often a need to move quickly. Overall, having the right support helps maintain my energy levels and focus throughout my shift, allowing me to provide the best care to my patients.
Thank you for sharing that. It’s clear that support plays a significant role in your performance. Can you describe the durability you expect from your work shoes?

Sure! I expect my work shoes to hold up to daily use over several months without falling apart. This means strong, durable materials that can endure a lot of walking and standing on different surfaces. The soles should be tough enough to stay intact and provide consistent support without wearing thin too quickly. Basically, I want shoes that can handle the demands of my job without losing their comfort or support before I'm ready to replace them.
That makes perfect sense, given the rigorous demands of your job. Are there any specific features you always look for in a shoe for work?

Absolutely! I always look for shoes with good arch support, cushioning, and slip-resistant soles. Breathable materials are a huge plus to keep my feet cooler during long shifts. I also like a roomy toe box to prevent any pinching or discomfort. These features all contribute to making sure I stay comfortable and safe while I’m on my feet all day.
Thank you for detailing those features, Jamie. Now, shifting gears a bit, how do you feel when your shoes don’t meet your expectations during a shift?

When my shoes don't meet my expectations, it can be really frustrating. It often leads to discomfort and distractions throughout my shift, which makes it harder to stay focused on my work and patient care. If my feet hurt or I'm worried about slipping, it can affect my ability to perform tasks efficiently. It’s a clear reminder of how important good footwear is in my job, and it pushes me to invest in quality shoes next time.
It sounds like having the right shoes is crucial for both your comfort and your performance. Does the brand of the shoe influence your purchasing decision? Why or why not?

The brand isn’t usually my first consideration, but it can matter because some brands have a reputation for making high-quality, comfortable shoes that are suitable for my work. If I've had good experiences with a brand in the past, I might be more inclined to consider their shoes again. However, it’s really more about the features and fit than the brand name itself. I’m open to trying different brands as long as they meet my needs for comfort, support, and durability.
It's interesting to hear that while the brand can be a factor, the features and fit are more critical. How important is the style or aesthetics of your work shoes?

Style and aesthetics are pretty low on my priority list when it comes to work shoes. I mean, it’s nice if they look good, but I’m much more focused on comfort, support, and safety features. As long as they meet those essential needs and are suitable for the hospital setting, I’m not too concerned about how stylish they are. Comfort really takes the front seat for me.
I appreciate your focus on functionality over style in a work environment. Considering the environment you work in, such as a hospital, how does that affect your footwear choice?

Working in a hospital greatly influences my footwear choice because the environment demands shoes that are not only comfortable for long hours but also safe and hygienic. I need shoes that have slip-resistant soles to prevent accidents on slick floors and materials that are easy to clean in case of spills or exposure to fluids. The hospital setting really requires that my shoes meet these practical standards to keep both me and my patients safe.

It's clear that the hospital environment sets a high bar for what your shoes need to provide. Have you ever made a footwear choice based on recommendations from peers? Can you elaborate on that experience?

Oh, definitely! Getting recommendations from colleagues is something I really value, especially since they understand the demands of the job. There was a time when a fellow nurse recommended a specific brand known for comfort and durability. I decided to try them out, and they ended up being one of the best pairs I've had for work. It was great to have their input and avoid the trial-and-error process on my own.
It sounds like peer recommendations can be incredibly valuable. Can you share a situation where you had to compromise on one feature of a shoe for another?

Sure! I remember once choosing a pair of shoes that had fantastic arch support and cushioning, but they were a bit heavier than I'd like. I compromised on the weight because I prioritized the comfort and support, especially given my long shifts. In the end, the shoes worked out well for me because the support helped with fatigue, which was ultimately more important than how light the shoes felt.
That sounds like a thoughtful trade-off to ensure you get the support you need. What typically triggers you to start considering purchasing a new pair of shoes?

I usually start thinking about getting a new pair of shoes when I notice they’re not as comfortable as they used to be or when my feet begin to feel fatigued more easily during a shift. If I see any signs of wear and tear, like the soles wearing thin or the support starting to give out, that's a trigger too. I pay attention to those little cues because they tell me it’s time to start looking for a replacement.
It makes sense to be attentive to those signs to maintain comfort and support. How do you make the final decision on which shoes to buy?

When making the final decision, I consider a few key factors. Comfort is always at the top of the list, so I try to go for a pair that feels good from the start. I look at the support features, like arch support and cushioning, and prioritize those that meet my needs. I also take into account any peer recommendations or reviews. If I’m unsure, I might try them on in-store to make sure they fit well and feel supportive. Balancing these factors usually helps me make a decision I’m happy with.
That sounds like a thorough and thoughtful process. Have you ever regretted a footwear purchase? What made you feel that way?

Yeah, I have regretted a purchase before. I once bought a pair of shoes online based on reviews but didn't try them on first. They ended up being too tight and not providing enough support, which became really uncomfortable during shifts. That experience taught me the importance of trying shoes on whenever possible, or at least making sure there's a good return policy if I need to exchange them.
I can see how that experience would emphasize the importance of a good fit. Which shoe brands do you associate with high-quality nursing shoes, and why?

I typically think of brands like Dansko and Brooks when it comes to high-quality nursing shoes. They have a reputation for offering great arch support and durability, which are key for someone on their feet all day. Many colleagues have also recommended them and I've had positive experiences with their comfort and longevity in the past.
It sounds like those brands have made a strong impression on you and your peers. How do you perceive the marketing messages from different shoe brands?

I usually take marketing messages with a grain of salt and prefer to rely on real-world experiences, like peer recommendations or reviews. But I do pay attention to marketing that focuses on comfort, support, and durability, as these are the features I care most about in work shoes. If a brand highlights these aspects and backs it up with customer testimonials, it might catch my interest a bit more.
It's great that you rely on practical experiences and testimonials. What are some common frustrations you face with current footwear options?

One common frustration is finding shoes that balance all the features I need, like support, comfort, and durability, without being too expensive. Sometimes, the options that provide great support can be a bit heavy or not too breathable. Another issue is sizing inconsistencies between brands, which makes online shopping tricky. It can be challenging to find the perfect pair that meets all my criteria without compromise.
I understand how those challenges could be frustrating. Can you recall a moment when you decided to switch brands or styles? What prompted that decision?

Absolutely. There was a time when my usual brand wasn't offering the durability I needed, and I found myself replacing them more often than expected. After talking to a colleague, I decided to try a different brand that was known for lasting longer. That switch was prompted by the need for more durability, which the new brand delivered, and I was really happy with that decision.
That's a great example of adapting to meet your needs. Are there any new products or innovations in footwear that have caught your attention recently?

I haven’t come across anything specific recently that stands out, but I'm always interested in innovations that focus on enhancing comfort and support, like better cushioning technology or more breathable materials. Anything that can make long shifts on my feet feel easier is definitely something I'd be open to exploring.
It's good to know you're open to new advancements in footwear technology. How open are you to trying new shoe brands or styles, and what factors influence this openness?

I’m pretty open to trying new shoe brands or styles, especially if they come recommended by colleagues or have good reviews. What's most important for me is that they meet my needs for comfort, support, and durability. The willingness to try something new is usually influenced by how well the shoes are marketed to solve specific issues I face, like foot fatigue or slippage during shifts. As long as I feel confident that they'll provide what I need, I'm willing to give them a shot.
It’s great that you’re open to exploring new options, especially with reliable recommendations. If you could change one thing about your current shoes, what would it be?

If I could change one thing about my current shoes, it would be to make them a bit lighter without compromising on support or comfort. Sometimes, after long hours, they can feel a bit heavy, and reducing that weight would make them even better for those long shifts.

Thank you for that insight, Jamie. It's always interesting to hear specific improvements users wish for. Is there anything else you’d like to share about your footwear preferences or experiences that we haven’t covered?

I think we've pretty much covered the essentials. Just to add, I've realized over time how crucial the right footwear is for my overall well-being and job performance, so I'm always on the lookout for shoes that can help me feel my best during those long shifts. It's one of those things where investing in quality really pays off for both comfort and health. Thanks for letting me share!

Thank you for sharing your detailed insights, Jamie. I really appreciate your time and openness. Before we conclude, do you have any suggestions for shoe designers looking to meet the needs of nurses better?

Sure thing! I'd suggest focusing on designing shoes that offer excellent arch support and cushioning while also being lightweight. Breathable materials are a huge help, too. Making sure the shoes are easy to clean and slip-resistant is vital for our work environment. And, of course, having a good range of sizes with consistent fits would make a big difference. It would also be great if designers could incorporate feedback from nurses to continuously improve their designs based on real-world experiences. Thanks for asking!

Thank you so much for those valuable suggestions, Jamie. They will certainly be helpful for designers aiming to meet the needs of nurses better. I really appreciate your time and insights today.

Before we wrap up, would you like to receive updates on the outcomes of this study?

Absolutely, I’d love to hear about the outcomes! It’s always interesting to see how feedback is used to make improvements, especially for something that's so important in my day-to-day work. Thank you for considering me for updates!
